context: Carriers have evolved since their inception in the early twentieth century from wooden vessels used <a0_0><b5_0>to deploy balloons<b5_0/><a0_0/> to nuclear-powered warships that carry dozens of aircraft, including fighter jets and helicopters. As of 3 March 2016, there are <a1_0><b6_0>thirty-seven<b6_0/><a1_0/> active aircraft carriers in the world within twelve navies. <a4_0><b9_0>The United States Navy<b9_0/><a4_0/> has 10 large nuclear-powered carriers (known as <a2_0>supercarriers<a2_0/>, carrying <a3_0><b8_0>up to 90<b8_0/><a3_0/> aircraft each), the largest carriers in the world; the total deckspace is over twice that of all other nations' combined. As well as the <b7_0>supercarrier<b7_0/> fleet, the US Navy has nine amphibious assault ships used primarily for helicopters (sometimes called helicopter carriers); these can also carry up to 25 fighter jets, and in some cases, are as large as some other nations' fixed-wing carriers.
